title: Sam Struthers (He/Him)
text:
Welcome!
Sam Struthers is currently a staff member at the ROSS lab at CSU.
His research is currently focusing on the water quality impacts of the Cameron Peak Wildfire and maintaining the Lower Poudre Sonde Network.
To learn more about the ROSS lab’s research <https://rossyndicate.com/>

This website was built using quarto and can it’s repository can be viewed here: Github Website Repository

title: About Me
text:
Hi!

My name is Sam Struthers and I am currently a researcher in the ROSS Lab at Colorado State University (Fort Collins).
I am very passionate about water resources in the Western US.
I hope to build my data science and analysis skills to help people all over the world be able to track water quality in their local watershed.
Outside of water, I love to rock climb with my specialty being bouldering. I also spend a lot time hiking, snowboarding and biking around town.

title: Photography
text: When working in the field, traveling or rock climbing, I enjoy capturing photos. I thought I might share a few I think are pretty good.

title: Current Work
text: Currently I am managing the field operations for two projects in the ROSS lab.

title: Past Work
text:
Installing high elevation site one month post fire!


Previously, I worked as a field technician for Dr Stephanie Kampf researching post-fire hydrologic responses. This work focused on the streamflow responses from changes in snow pack characteristics. Dr Kampf and others published this paper on that work: Increasing wildfire impacts on snowpack in the western U.S.



Deepest snowpit for the season!


Through this work, I got experience installing various sensors and learning methods to measure snowpack and streamflow. I also learned how to qualitatively assess watershed characteristics through site selection and watershed surveys.



Field visit to 6 small catchments to determine suitability for future studies.

title: Current Work
text:
The Upper Poudre Network:



Peterson Lake late, one of the burned reservoirs in our study.


I currently manage a team of field and lab technicians who collect water grab samples in the Cache La Poudre River with the goal of understanding how water quality in high elevation reservoirs change post- wildfire. This project will also eventually include water quality sondes which will be used to help warn downstream users when water quality is impaired from either algal blooms or sedimentation.

title: Current Work
text:
The Lower Poudre Network:
My primary duties are to install, maintain and calibrate seven water quality sondes on the Cache La Poudre River above, through and below the city of Fort Collins to track changes in water quality.








Two sites in our Lower Poudre Monitoring Network
